titleStmt.title: A briefe exposition, paraphrase, or interpretation, upon the Lord of Canterburies sermon or speech, upon the last pulpit that ever he preached, which was the scaffold on Tower-hill. Also, upon the prayer which he used at the same time and place before his execution. Written by William Starbucke Gentleman, to give the people a glimmering of the Bishops hypocrisie.
titleStmt.author: Starbuck, William.

titleStmt.title: A briefe exposition, paraphrase, or interpretation, upon the Lord of Canterburies sermon or speech, upon the last pulpit that ever he preached, which was the scaffold on Tower-hill. Also, upon the prayer which he used at the same time and place before his execution. Written by William Starbucke Gentleman, to give the people a glimmering of the Bishops hypocrisie.

notesStmt.note: The woodcut frontispiece has title "The full view of Canterburies fall, from POP deliver us all". Although the leaf is identified as a broadside in Wing (F2380), all copies seen are bound with the work by Starbuck.
Annotation on Thomason copy: The 5 in the imprint date has been crossed out; "Jan: 22nd 1644".
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE FULL VIEW OF Canterburies fall, From POP deliver us all.

p.hi: Grace, and no grace, Hath wrought thy di≈øgrace.

lg.l: My head that wrought all mi≈øery
You Prelats be warned by me,
the reward of evill ju≈øt you ≈øee

div.p: A Briefe EXPOSITION, PARAPHRASE, OR INTERPRETATION, UPON THE Lord of Canterburies Sermon or Speech, upon the la≈øt Pulpit that ever he preached, which was the Scaffold on Tower-hill.
Al≈øo, upon the Prayer which he u≈øed at the ≈øame time and place before his Execution.
Written by William Starbucke Gentleman, to give the people a glimmering of the Bi≈øhops hypocri≈øie.
div.q: MATTH. 7.15. Beware of fal≈øe Prophets which come to you in ≈øheeps cloathing, but inwardly they are ravening wolves.
PROVERB. 26.24. He that hateth di≈ø≈øembling with his lips, and layeth up deceit within him: when he ≈øpeakes faire believe him not, for there are ≈øeven abominations in his heart.
div.p: LONDON Printed for William Starbuck. 1645.

div.head: To the Chri≈øtian READER.
div.p:
CHri≈øtian Reader, I know your expectations, or your de≈øires by your Queres, Que≈øtions, An≈øwers, and Objections; or rather indeed by many of your di≈øtractions: to wit, What do you think of my Lord of Canterbury his Speech or Sermon? how did you like it? To which Queres, Que≈øtions, An≈øwers, Objections, and Di≈øtractions, I will give as briefe an an≈øwer as I may, for the≈øe rea≈øons: fir≈øt, in regard of my little time; for things in this nature require ha≈øt. Secondly, of my unability, for there
is ≈øuch deepe my≈øteries, as Latine, and other ≈øentences, that I and many more cannot finde out the depth of it in a ≈øhort time, and it may be never, in regard of his hypocri≈øie. Thirdly, too Eccl. 12. much writing or reading is a wearine≈ø≈øe both to the writer and reader.

Fir≈øt, what doe you thinke of his Sermon or repentance? my skill or under≈øtanding deceiveth me, if Judas his repentance were not as good, and Achans, if not both rather better: for Judas confe≈ø≈øed a particular ≈øin, not onely, I have ≈øinned, but, I have ≈øinned in betraying the Mat. 27.4. innocent blood. Achan likewi≈øe, not, I am a ≈øinner, or onely, I have ≈øinned again≈øt the Lord; but, thus and thus have I done, I ≈øaw a Babyloni≈øh garment, and two wedges of Gold, and I coveted them. In doing this, the Text ≈øaith, he gave glory, unto the Io≈øh 7.19, 20 Lord God. But how many of the Saints of God ≈øtood and ≈øate looking with their eyes, and hearing with their eares, and de≈øiring with their prayers, that God would, if it were his will, give him repentance, who≈øe innocent blood he had been the arch ≈øpiller of, ≈øome of them, or their friends; witne≈ø≈øe Ma≈øter Burton, Mr. Prynne, Doctor Ba≈øtwicke, and Mr. Lilburne, be≈øides the man that was put to death as a Traytor, for him, which it may be ≈øaw the ≈øpilling of his, ≈øome of them: how many were
there; nay rather, how many thou≈øands, which ≈øome of them he had been the arch impri≈øoner of; laying waite for the Prov. 14.15. righteous, and ≈øpoiling them of their re≈øting place, cau≈øing them to flie from one Pari≈øh to another, one Towne to another, one City to another; nay, from one Land to another, many into New-England, ≈øome to the We≈øt-Indies, and other places of the World: which of any of all the≈øe heard this Merchant, or great man of the earth, which by his policy robd and deceived the Nations, waxing rich by his ≈øorceries, to confe≈ø≈øe any ≈øinne or ≈øinnes, to Ezek. 18.17. re≈øtore any pledge or pledges, either publiquely, or privately; aske Mis. S.I. and others, which have been with him, and then judge of my thoughts; and parallel Juda≈øes and Achans repentance, and then tell me, which of them is the wor≈øt: and now, as in a wilderne≈ø≈øe, not knowing how to get out, I end my Epi≈øtle, and begin to ≈øu≈øpend my thoughts upon his Speech or Sermon; and where I come too ≈øhort, I refer you to Ma≈øter Prynnes, Deeds of darkne≈ø≈øe, which I heare ≈øay is comming forth, if it be not already.

epigraph.q: Let us run with patience the race that is ≈øet before us, looking unto Je≈øus the Author and fini≈øher of our faith, who for the joy that was ≈øet before him indurd the Cro≈ø≈øe, de≈øpi≈øing the ≈øhame, and is ≈øet down at the right hand of the Throne of God.

div.head: The VVriters Apology.
div.p: GOod people, my Apology is, as my Lord ≈øaith in a nother ca≈øe, that you would pardon my boldne≈ø≈øe, if I follow the Prophets expre≈ø≈øions to the prie≈øts of Baall, who≈øe Sermon I have heer to deale with, although as ≈øeldom as I may which was ironically ≈øpoken: cry aloud, it may be he is in a journey, or a≈øleepe; which was the preachers practice to both young and old, Rejoyce young man in thy youth, and let thy heart cheere thee in the dayes of thy youth: and walke in the wayes of thy heart, (as he did) and in the ≈øight of thine eyes: but for all the≈øe things God will bring thee unto judgement.

div.head: The Bi≈øhops Apology.
div.p: FIr≈øt, before my Lord begun his Sermon he de≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ed the good people to pardon his old memory, but by right he ≈øhould have craved pardon when he was younger, for his memory was as ill to be tru≈øted then as now, but at that time he granted out ≈øo many pardons to others, and ab≈øolutions, that he forgot his own, or el≈øe it ≈ølipt out of his memory; but it may be, he had it from the Pope long ≈øince, and then it might be in his Study or in ≈øome little blacke box, and ≈øo as ≈øafe as his own Licence or the re≈øt of the prie≈øts, that was made by him or his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors.

Secondly, he told us upon what oca≈øion he came thither, included in the≈øe words, I am come; he came indeed, but he mu≈øt needs come when he could not tell how to helpe it; for had not the Sheriffes and their Officers, according to an Ordinance of Parliament, brought him thither, as Eli≈øha ≈øaid in another ca≈øe, ≈øo ≈øay I, you ≈øhould not have ≈øeene his face that day, e≈øpecially upon, or in that pulpit.

Thirdly, he ≈øaid he mu≈øt make u≈øe of his paper; he dare not tru≈øt him≈øelfe otherwi≈øe: but for my part I thin he he never had a ≈øtronger motive to ≈øtir up his memory, ≈øo that if he had never preached but upon a paper all hi ‚Ä¢ life before, he might have throwne away his paper then except his Sermon had been longer, but he that hath not the Spirit to depend upon, to bring things into his memory, and hath not a mouth and wi≈ødome given him from God, he mu≈øt needs tru≈øt to ≈øomething, let him tru≈øt to his paper.

Fourthly, and la≈øtly he ≈øaith, good people, but he leaves out all, you know what he meanes, that is an uncomfortable
place to Preach in. I grant it, for if no afflictions are joyous to the gooly for the pre≈øent, then much more no puni≈øhments to the wicked, for the prophet ≈øaith no peace
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
≈øpeaketh my God to the wicked: be≈øides to preach glad tidings unto others and his own Funerall Sermon, it was „Äà‚óä„Äâ an uncomfortable time, but the place was good enough‚ñ™ for he never had more roome, (had the ≈øcaffold been but empty) nor yet a greater audience of people; ≈øo much for his Apology, now I come to the ‚Ä¢ ex Heb. 12.1.2.

As his memory was not to be tru≈øted to, but his paper, and his place very uncomfortable, ≈øo his time was very ≈øhort, for he wanted time, otherwi≈øe he would have devided his Text; but to ≈øhow his ≈ø ‚Ä¢ holler≈øhip in too many places, (though it would not have charged his memory, yet his paper,) being charged in the 7. 10. 13. 14, 18, 19. pages too much Latine, except it had bin all interpreted, or el≈øe he mighth ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ve been affraid of this word us: for this word us would have ≈øhewed, that it was meant the ≈øaints, and not Traitors or impenitent Malefactors, for the cloud of witne≈ø≈øes before u≈øed, were ≈øuch as were per≈øecuted by ≈øuch as him≈øelfe, them≈øelves being no per≈øecuter; He ≈øaith he hath bin long running the Race, I canno ‚Ä¢ ≈øay ≈øo, a Race, but not the Race: for if he had begun, Chri≈øt which was the Author, would have him the fini≈øher, or if he had bin the fini≈øher, he would have fini≈øhed his worke better, therefore you ≈øay well, you are come to the end of your owne Race. You ≈øay that the ≈øhame mu≈øt be de≈øpi≈øed, or el≈øe there is no comming to the crowne, I had thought the crowne had bin come to by the free grace of God, and ≈øufferings and effect, in tho≈øe which have received the a≈ø≈øurance, but now I ≈øee your Arminiani≈øm and your generall Redemntion although you have kept it clo≈øe, you tell us he hath de≈øpi≈øed the ≈øhame for you, then Chri≈øt hath
died for all, and if he died for all, then all ≈øhall be ≈øaved, Indas ≈øhare and yours is as good as the re≈øt of the Di≈øciples, and he de≈øpi≈øed the ≈øhame for Chri≈øt though he crucified him. He ≈øaith, that be is going apace toward the red Sea, his feet being upon the brink, and it is an argument, that God is bringing him to the Land of promi≈øe, and that he in≈øtituted a Pa≈ø≈øover for them; ≈øo Pharaoh was going a pace toward the read ≈øea when he per≈øecuted the children of I≈ørael; a poore argument that ever he ≈øhould come to the land of Canaan, but he was drowned in the ≈øea again≈øt his wil, ≈øo you, whil≈øt your chariot wheels were on, but now you are come to the red Sea again≈øt your will, ≈øo as Pharaoh and all his ho≈øt were drowned, your head hath bin chopt off, and your red bloud run about the ≈øcaffold: but I≈ørael pa≈ø≈øed thorough dry≈øhod and triumphed over Pharaoh and all his Ho≈øt, as the ≈øaints do now over you, your head being chopt off; the Pa≈ø≈øover was in≈øtituted but for I≈ørael, and the Lord pa≈øt them by, but the fir≈øt borne of Pharaoh were all ≈ølaine; ≈øo God hath pa≈ø≈øed by tho≈øe which you have per≈øecuted, and you are catched in the ≈øame ≈ønare; Hagaion & ≈øelah. As for your dige≈øting the ≈øoure Herbs, you mu≈øt whether you will or no: and for your being not angry; it is becau≈øe your Horns be cut off, the day hath been, when you would not have been well plea≈øed with the hearing tell of ≈øuch ≈øoure and bitter Herbs: and though you were a chiefe Bi≈øhop you mi≈øtake Chri≈øts example, for when hee prayeth that the Cup might pa≈ø≈øe from him, he prayeth ≈øo, that the people might under≈øtand him, and the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith, bee will pray with the ≈øpirit and with under≈øtanding al≈øo: el≈øe how could they that occupied the roome of the unlearned ≈øay Amen?

In the next place you ≈øee, though he had ≈øome faith ≈øuch a one as it was; that I≈ørael was ≈øaved and their enemies
drowned, and the three Children freed from the fiery furnace, and they that put them in burned, ≈øo that he ≈øhould be delivered, and they which hee ≈øuffered under ≈øhould ≈øuffer them≈øelves; but hee wanted a Revelation for that. He told us al≈øo, that his re≈øolution was as the three Childrens, and not to wor≈øhip the Image which the King had ≈øet up: telling us that the people had ≈øet up their imaginations, ≈øaying, that he would not for≈øake the Temple and Truth, to follow the bleating of Ierobvames Calves in Dan and Bethell; you ≈øee his thoughts of the erecting wor≈øhip, but hee ≈øayd nothing of the bleating of the Sheepe, and the lowing of the Oxen, which where in Pauls and many other places puld downe by Order of Parliament; though formerly reedified by him≈øelfe. He prayed that God would open the Peoples eyes, that they might ≈øee the right way, for if the blind lead the blind they will both fall into the ditch, it was well con≈øidered, for he had led ≈øo many into the ditch him≈øelfe, that except they ≈øee a righter way then he led them, will not get out in ha≈øt.

And as for his Repentance looke into the Epi≈øtle to the Reader, but behold what a foule heart he had: for after he had ran≈øaked it hee found no ≈øinnes there (they being hid as Saul was among≈øt the ≈øtuffe,) that de≈øerved Death by any ju≈øt Lawes of this Kingdome: here is worke for the Parliament, he meanes it may be repealing worke, though he cleares the Judges with his mouth, yet there might be ≈øeven abominations in his heart, for I am ≈øure hee condemns the witne≈ø≈øes, and leaving Chri≈øt, he takes comfort in Elfegus; you ≈øee that hee keeps his Supremacy ≈øtill, as the Pope, which ≈øaith, that he is Chri≈øts Viegerent upon Earth, forgetting what Chri≈øt ≈øaid to his Apo≈øtler, let him that it chiefe among≈øt you be your ≈øervant: call no man Lord, for one is your Lord which is Ie≈øus Chri≈øt; bee not Lords
over Gods heritage; you ≈øee hee tumbles good cau≈øes and bad together, and good per≈øons and bad together: daubing up his comforts with Iohn the Bapti≈øt, Paul, and Steven, and with ancient Fathers, as the Papi≈øts his Brethren doe.

He ≈øaid al≈øo that the Pope had never ≈øuch a Harve≈øt in his life, but if it ≈øhould come to the Popes care, he would give him little thanks for his report; if Heading, Hanging, Drawing and Quartering, cutting off Archbi≈øhops hea ‚Ä¢ s be ≈øuch a harve≈øt, he will not medle with it, take th ‚Ä¢ cro ‚Ä¢ who will.

You ≈øee al≈øo what a favorite hee was to the King, and and how he knowes his mind; and who was his coun≈øellor or Achitophel; but I remember Pharaoh he ≈øaw it plea≈øed the people and ≈øo he proceeded further.

Citizens cleare your ≈øelves, for you are taxed by my Lords Booke for going to the Parliament, to cry out for Ju≈øtice, and there is Scripture again≈øt you‚ñ™ ≈øo that by con≈øequence for this great crime you wil bring innocent bloud on your ≈øelves, but it may bee hee gives you this caution to make the People thinke him≈øelfe Innocent and you guilty.

Now I am come to my Lords lamentation for the poore Church of England, while≈øt my Lord was Arch-governour, you were kept in good order, all things went well, Pauls went up apace, all the re≈øt of the hou≈øes were puld down that prophaned it, Organs repaired, and not pulled downe, I puni≈øhed tho≈øe that ≈øpake again≈øt the Service Booke; the Singers al≈øo had their wages, but now in≈øtead of ≈øinging longs of alacrity, they ≈øing ≈øongs of lacrymae. Profanene≈ø≈øe comes in, and is already, the high Commi≈ø≈øion Court is put downe, every man may doe what hee lift, the≈øe Puritans, Roundheads, may doe what they plea≈øe, whereas I could have ≈ølit their No≈øes, cut their
Eares, ≈øet them on the Pilory, Starved, Impri≈øoned, Compelled them to bla≈øpheme as Paul did, and per≈øecuted them unto ≈øtrange Cities.

The la≈øt particular, (for my Lord made ha≈øte, becau≈øe the head≈ø-man ≈øtaid for him) be tels us of his birth, where he was borne and baptized; to wit, in the Church of England: but he forgetteth Sion, which ≈øaith, this man was borne there, and that Jeru≈øalem which is from above is the mother of us all. Although he hath been a ruler in England, we have not yet one word of his new birth. But ≈øome of his Chaplains would have done well to have preached out of the third of Iohn upon his Ma≈øters Pulpit, rather then to have let him preached him≈øelfe; it may be that might have done him ≈øome good, and hindred him from ≈øending abroad his hypocriticall or Je≈øuiticall poy≈øon into the world, and wre≈øting of Scriptures to his owne pardition.

Al≈øo he ≈øaith, this is no time for to di≈ø≈øemble. Is not this the way of all Je≈øuits, to die with m ‚Ä¢ ntall re≈øervation according to Law, who knows his meaning‚ñ™ telling us of his innocencie, how he laboured to keepe an uniformity; yea and did, one with the Pope; and would have done with Scotland al≈øo, by ≈øending of his poy≈øon thither, if God had not prevented him in his owne time. Al≈øo, what clamours of the people hath he ≈øuffered; how have they clamored, or rather cried out of him for impri≈øoning of their husbands, children, and friends, robbing them by his Pur≈øevants, ≈øilencing, and turning wife and children out of doores. He proceeds, and contrary to all witne≈ø≈øes, and proceedings of Parliament, cleares him≈øelfe from Trea≈øon, or what≈øoever is laid again≈øt him; but as good a Lawyer as he was, let Ma≈øter Prynne alone with him, he
hath per≈øecuted him once for his ≈øincerity, but now he hath or will lay open his hypocri≈øie. He ≈øaith he would not enlarge him≈øelfe, and ≈øo forgives others, and would have others forgive him; he derogates a little from his former practi≈øes in the High-commi≈ø≈øion-Court: for then he granted out forgivene≈ø≈øes for others, and asked none him≈øelfe; de≈øiring them to joyne with him in prayer, (though Salomon ≈øaith, that the prayers of the wicked are an abomination to the Lord,) the manner and matter being both fal≈øe. God promi≈øed that he would poure upon the hou≈øe of David the Spirit of prayer and ≈øupplication. Paul prayed with the ≈øpirit and under≈øtanding al≈øo, and ≈øaith, that the Spirit helpeth the infirmities which cannot be uttered by them; at the day of Penteco≈øt, or the
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . fiftieth day, the Spirit came downe in cloven tongues, not Books, Beads or Crucifixes: but my Lord though he was ar ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , was not there, therefore excu≈øe him. He de≈øired the Lord to looke upon him, but not till he was bathed in the blood of Chri≈øt: here you ≈øee he que≈øtions his a≈ø≈øurance. He prayes that the King and his po≈øterity, and the people may be e≈øtabli≈øhed in their ju≈øt Lawes, and ancient liberties: you know what he meanes.

div.head: Some Ob≈øervations upon Sir John Clotworthys Que≈øtions, and my Lords An≈øwers.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: SIr Iohn Clothworthy a≈øked him, what ≈øpeciall place of Scripture was mo≈øt comfortable now at his departure.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: He an≈øwers in Latin, that he de≈øires to be di≈ø≈øolved, and to be with Chri≈øt.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: You ≈øee, as he has got his honour by learning, ≈øo he lo≈øeth his honour with learning. The Go≈øpell ≈øaith, If any ≈øpeake in anunknown Tongue, let it be interpreted. As al≈øo, that he had rather ≈øpeake five words that he might teach others, then ten thou≈øand words in an unknowne Tongue. But my Lord forgot that.

sp.speaker: J.
sp.p: Sir Iohn Clothworthy told him, that was a good de≈øire, but there mu≈øt be a foundation for that de≈øire, as a≈ø≈øurance.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: He an≈øwers, that no man can expre≈ø≈øe it, it was to be found within.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: A fit man to be a Bi≈øhop; doth not the Scripture ≈øay, With the heart man believeth to ≈øalvation, and with the tongue confe≈ø≈øion is made.

sp.speaker: I.
sp.p: Sir John Clothworthy ≈øaid, It is founded on a word, and that word would be knowne.

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: He an≈øwered, That word is the knowledge of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, and him alone.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: But my Lord came too ≈øhort of giving Sir Iohn ≈øatisfaction according to his que≈øtion. Tho≈øe that have the knowledge of Chri≈øt within them are able to expre≈ø≈øe it to others. But my Lord ≈øatisfied us not that the Lord is within him.

div.head: TO THE READER on the Authors name.

l.hi: WHen I did heare the people to admire,
With zeale my heart did burne like any fire.
What they did ≈øpeake, and I my ≈øelfe did thinke
Will I write down with Paper, and with Inke.
Iniquity to heare them to commend,
I had done ill if it I bad ‚Ä¢ not pend.
I hearing ill extold, and good cald evill,
It to pa≈ø≈øe by, in me had been uncivill.
Looke and behold, and ≈øee how they applaud

lg.l: Like to a God, I meane their little Laud.

l.hi: Like to a martyr do they thinke he dy'd,
Lo by the law a malefactor try'd.
Looke not on men, they are but du≈øt and clay,
Like to a ≈øhade from hence away they pa≈ø≈øe,
Like to a dream, a bubble, or like gra≈ø≈øe.
I doe admire, and yet admire I not,
In this plaine ca≈øe you ≈øhould be ≈øo be≈øot.
If in his life ≈øo many were bereaved,
In death much more they well might be deceived.
Alas poore ≈øoules, ≈øuch thoughts as the≈øe a ≈øhun,
Above looke up, and ≈øee what God hath done,
Admire and wonder at his Parliament,
And leave ≈øuch thoughts as give your ≈øelves content.
Murthers and trea≈øons till they have ≈øuppre≈øt,
Minutes, nights, houres, taking little re≈øt:
Maintaining innocents in a right cau≈øe,
Malignants puni≈øhing that break the Laws.
Such that in pri≈øon once were forc'd to lie,
Strange Countreys al≈øo forced for to flie,
Seeking for ≈øhelter, wandring up and down,
Set are in places now of great renown.
Tho No≈øes ≈ølit, impri≈øoned, lo≈øt their Eares,
They much re≈øpected are of Noble Peeres.
Tho Bi≈øhops once upon them much did frown,
The Prelates prond for them are pulled down.
All you that captives were, and now ≈øet free,
Above your voices lift you up with me;
Admire and wonder at ≈øuch things as the≈øe,
At God alone, and let him have the prai≈øe.
Rai≈øe up your heads, and clap your hands for joy,
Remember how he doth your foes de≈øtroy:
Revive a little tho they doe and ≈øpread,
Rotten they be, and ≈øoon they will be dead.
Blood which is innocent, he that doth ≈øpill,
Blood he him≈øelfe ≈øhall drinke again≈øt his will.

lg.l: Blood again≈øt Caine aloud to Heaven cryed,

l.hi: ∆≤nto all you I doe my ≈øpeech direct,
∆≤nity which as yet doe not affect;
∆≤nto the Lord, and never give him leave
∆≤ntill in mercy he doe you receive.
Call unto God that he would give you grace,
Cry unto him whil≈øt you have time and ≈øpace.
Crave pardon now before that you be dead,
Cau≈øe you the blood of innocents have ≈øhed.
Keep in your hearts the≈øe Ver≈øes few of mine,
Know what they meane, and con them time by time,
Ki≈ø≈øe exhortations good, and eke embrace,
Know God in time, to day ≈øeeke you his face.
